The bar has a cross-sectional area A and is subjected to the axial load P. Determine the average normal stresses acting over the shaded section, which is oriented at $\theta$ from the horizontal. <image 1>

A. P/(A)*sin(2$\theta$)
B. (P/A)sin^2($\theta$)
C. P/(2A)*sin(2$\theta$)
D. (P/2A)sin^2($\theta$)

To determine the average normal stress acting over the shaded section, we need to consider the orientation of the stress vector relative to the cross-sectional area. The shaded section is oriented at an angle $\theta$ from the horizontal.

The average normal stress $\sigma$ can be calculated using the formula:

\[
\sigma = \frac{P}{A} \cdot \cos(\theta)
\]

This formula accounts for the orientation of the stress vector relative to the cross-sectional area. Since the stress vector is oriented at an angle $\theta$ from the horizontal, the cosine of this angle is $\cos(\theta)$.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

D. (P/2A)sin^2($\theta$)
